ideas.why: Higher US tariffs signal tougher import barriers. Domestic steelmakers gain pricing power and demand protection. Assumes tariffs persist and exemptions are limited.
US neo-mercantilism favors domestic manufacturing inputs. Nucor benefits from reduced foreign steel competition. Assumes infrastructure and industrial demand hold.
Escalating trade frictions risk spillovers into broader US-China economic relations, hurting Chinese exporters and sentiment. Assumes tensions widen beyond goods tariffs.
Global pushback against Chinese manufacturing dominance raises tariff and market-access risks. Export-heavy manufacturers face near-term pressure. Assumes more countries adopt barriers.
Trade fragmentation and tariffs reduce global trade volumes. Container shipping demand weakens. Assumes no rapid trade détente.

key_assumptions: US tariffs remain elevated for several months
China does not rapidly stimulate domestic demand to offset exports
No immediate multilateral trade agreement is reached
